Jazz? Yes, please. This could be great!
Close but no cigar. Kids on the slope is one of those semi-quality anime shows that pulls you in and then makes you go: "Where in the name of Batman's balls did my jazz show disappear?" Time and time again. 
Look, I know that it's a show about relationships as well but if you are going to hook the audience with something as intriguing as "nerdy classical pianist meets wild child meathead jazz drummer and you know that they are going to be jam buddies and you will want to know how" then it better pay off. But justlike my master's degree in philosophy, it doesn't. Oh sure, there's plenty of highschool romance stuff in there everyone. And we all know how rare that stuff is. \n\n
That being said, this is still much better than you're average anime. So much in fact that it made, even me, the hater of probably 95% out there, watch it neatly to the end. The show lacks many of the usual anime vices, like the out-of-place-boob-grab and the stripper-outfit-as-everyday-life-clothing. The dialogue has no glaring "I will explain what just happened although you just saw it" either. I wont be running around naked in the snow for Kids on the slope (like that one weekend with Monster - my gawd) but it's a nice watch, if you can stomach the highschool/romance stuff. 8/10.

So, it's just outstanding anime about jazz, 1960s and human circumstances. Down here I'll describe shortly this point.
Plot is really stunning: can anyone name an anime, where music and story are really connected and can't be represented separately? Can anyone name an anime, where motivations of all characters are unbelievable realistic and define all twists? Can, in the upshot, anyone name an anime, where zeitgest is really felt?!
Second powerful point of this show is music. I never liked jazz, but after watching this I'll definitely pay respect of fans of this music genre, at least.
Art and enjoyment are both 8.5/10, but they aren't so importanthere.\n\n
Overall rating is 10/10. Many thanks to all involved in creating of this amazing full-realistic anime.

Sakamichi no Apollon (Which will be now referred to as Kids on the Slope) is an anime, set in the mid 1960s, about 3 angst stricken classmates who come together through music.
The main focus is really on Kaoru, a quiet loner who never makes any friends, and Sentarou, a brash school delinquent. They essentially have opposite backgrounds, family lives, personalities, school standings, body types, etc. The show is a lot about how one has an effect on the other. There is of course also Ritsuko, Sentarou's childhood friend, and the daughter of the owner of the record shop the group will practice in. 
There arealso two side characters, Brother Jun and Yurika. They will be involved heavily in some romance sub-plots (and also be a cause of a great deal of confusion around the middle of the show). A lot of this show is about the romance, bromance, and mistaken romances of the characters.


The characters, especially Kaoru go through some pretty nice development, however, there are issues. Kaoru especially is the type of character who will make choices that will infuriate you, many of them because of the pure childishness they exhibit. Even Sentarou, who I'd consider to be the best character in the show, makes an extremely rash and out of character decision. The progression of the show is good, but some of the drama used to get there is not.


A show that a lot of people will compare this to is Nodame Cantabile. However, Nodame Cantabile does something that Kids on the Slope does not... have comedy. While I understand KotS is not a comedy (and Nodame is) there is almost ZERO comedy in all of KotS. So it's basically all built of tension episode after episode and the end results is that it seems a bit tiring.


Obviously one of the main draws to the show is going to be the music. Well, there is some music. The thing is it's not the focus of the show. If you think they form a jazz band or something, they don't. It's just used for them to play and basically let out their emotions. This leads to another issue, if you don't like the over the top, notes everywhere type jazz then the music will be a real detractor for you. 


So, for all the negative sounding things I've said about the show it's actually fairly decent. It has well thought out (albeit often infuriating) characters and a real good sense of character driven drama (although they go overboard). Yes, the show will make you feel things, but what they do is totally based on you.

Oh, Sakamichi no Apollon. How I love you and how I hate you; why did you have to be so good but with such obvious, glaring, painful flaws? 
Story: 6
The story (synopsis available above) is pretty simply. It's simple without the need to get convoluted and is very enjoyable with it's innocent fun but... here comes my biggest issue with the show; it's not handled very well. 
To avoid spoilers I won't go into details: there are concepts introduced which don't show up for long periods of time, seeming like they were forgotten or copped out because of time restrains. Transitions between time 'skips' (forlack of a better term) is awkwardly handled, leaving the audience to piece together how much time has passed with very little indication for no reason and, my biggest issue, the extremely sporadic pacing. The pacing is all over the place in this show; some parts are calm and collected while others go from one thing to another so fast that there's little time to take anything in. 


Art: 8


The character designs are very 'normal' (for the most part) without the need for flashy in-your-face characters or deformed bodies. The art is overall quite nice and the close-up shots on the instruments are pleasing to the eye. Very fitting with the rest of the show leaving no complaints. 


Sound: 10 


This is probably bias speaking, especially since jazz is one of my favourite genres--and the 'main' song "Moanin'" by Art Blakey being one of my favourites--but the sound of this show was damn near perfect. The voice acting was good and there were no overblown reactions for comedic purpose (that I remember), sound effects were fitting, and the music selection left little to be desired. 


Characters: 9


I could go off on numerous tangents about each of the [important] characters but to save time and space: 


they were all well written with their own motivations, reasoning, likable and irritable traits, they had fitting reactions and were, in my honest opinion, more relatable/human/'natural' than in most other anime. Although some development is lacking, the execution more than makes up for it if I say so myself. 


Overall: 8.


As much as I loved this anime there were numerous issues with the story which I found to be greatly detrimental to the overall show but not enough to make me dislike it. It's a show I'd definitely recommend and think stands on a solid 8/10.

It's an anime with a ton of Jazz music. Not much to say here except that whether or not one is a fan of jazz music, you are in for what is arguably one of the most well orchestrated and arranged soundtracks in recent anime productions. Combined with the fluidity of the show's animation, Kids on the Slope is a model of visual and musical entertainment, culminating in impressive musical numbers at several key points within the series. 
It's also an anime about life in small town Japan during the 1960's. Aside from putting on a great show, there is significan meaning behind the music,for it is a representation of the time and setting of this anime. The anime references a number of famous real life jazz artists and their music, thus illustrating the inherent influence of American culture during the decade. Indeed, the show's music and they way it transforms from one stylistic genre to another draws parallels to the changes in one's life with the passage of time. 


Most of all, the narrative tells the story of an unlikely duo consisting of an introverted study-bug in Kaoru Nishimi and his counterpart, the brash school delinquent Sentaro Kawabuchi. Having only a knack for music in common, yet they are brother's in every sense except for blood; The bond these two main characters share only grows as the series progresses. This level of  platonic character development is not only rare in slice of life dramas but also frequently drowned out in favor of more cliched romances, and contrived tragedies. 


Louis Armstrong once said  "The memory of things gone is important to a jazz musician." In keeping with that, Kaoru and Sentaro's bond with their friends (and each other) is epitomized, and later on immortalized in remembrance by their numerous jazz numbers together. 


In short, there's a lot to like about this series and I hope you enjoy this series as much as I did. "Kids on the Slope" is an excellent slice of life story that draws a lot of empathy for its characters, while at the same time director Shinchiro Watanabe evokes his signature jazz themed narrative in collaboration, for the second time, with the talented Yoko Kanno (Their first collaboration over 15 years ago yielded the now anime classic "Cowboy Bebop"). 



Whil I hope you found this review helpful, I am always trying to make my reviews better, so constructive feedback would be much appreciated ( just leave a post on my wall ). Or, if you wanna just talk about this series ( or anime in general ) you can do that too!

My opinion is kind of separated in two opposed thoughts.
The first one is that Kids on the slope is a really beautiful anime about music, and especially jazz. The ost is awesome, the different sessions between the characters are amazing, and the different renditions of some of the legendary jazz songs are all excellent.
Each time Kaoru and Sentarou was about to play, I knew I was going to enjoy the thing. Not only the music was amazing, but the way it was used is fascinating. The characters were using music to express their feelings, providing various and colorful renditions of a same song whitin the12 episodes. Sometimes, they wouldn't speak to each other, but would simply use instruments to discuss and solve their problems. Trully a very thoughtful and poetic way to speak about music in an anime.\n\n
The second one is about the romance aspect. I think this anime is really killed by the romance, which take a huge (even enormous)  place. I had read that this anime was into that kind of thing, but I was hoping something not that boring. Each time there was romance, all the characters were kind of dumb, acting weird and making no sense. Kaoru acted like an autist, Sentarou like someone with no willpower and Ri-chan like a vane, all of them enable to speak with each other.\n
I mean, I'm ok with a bit of romance (I'm not really into it but if it's just a bit I won't complain), but when it takes 3/4 of the anime in a boring way, I can't pass through it.\n
It's even more a pity, considering the other aspects treated in the anime (family issues, passage from child to adult is kinda good, even if I didn't understand that episode with Kaoru's mother (since it didn't impact at all the rest of the anime).\n\n
So, it's quite balanced. I liked it for the music, but I was completely bored by the romance. I was about to rate this anime 6/10, but well, it's worth watch it, despite the dumb romance. 7 should be fine for one of the most beautiful anime about music and jazz.

How do I even start ... if you're looking for a 12 episode Masterpiece, THIS IS IT!!! The first thing that got me into it is the genre, historical drama. The settings is drawn magnificently, we're in the late '60, Japan, the olympics are a fond recollection, the war is a distant memory, and Neil Armstrong hasn't landed on the moon yet. A rich, slightly cowardly teenager makes friends with the school bully through their love of music, and by music I mean jazz. The atmosphere is bohemian, there's also a girl, there's always a girl, but I would be spoiling you if I'd dwelveany deeper. This anime in all seriousness has changed who I am, how I see life, how preconceptions can become opportunities, how love and friendship might or might not end. The art is simply gorgeous, no bad CG here, no any type of CG LOL. About the music. First, this isn't a musical anime, like Hibike or La corda d'oro. This is drama, with characters that rejoice in music. That said, the legendary Yoko Kanno signes the score, and right from the opening you know this isn't your randon 1 cours anime. In terms of character progression there's a lot to talk about, but I would be spoiling you so I'll refrain myself to saying that things aren't what you'd expect in this anime, neither the characters nor the story. Needless to say, I give it a 10 out of 10. Hope you enjoy it, even if drama might not be your mainstay, you know we've talked about preconceptions, but once you do see it, you'll get hooked. Good bye for now.

This is my first time finishing a josei anime, and I made the right decision choosing this as my first.
Basically it's about a smart but quiet boy's relationship with a delinquent, which eventually turned into best friend after discovering they both have the same love for jazz, this anime has a complex love relationship (like in Nagi no asukara), also it contains a lot of drama that feels pretty realistic. The friendship between the 2 mc is truly the highlight of the anime. And I enjoyed the music even thought I'm not into jazz.
The downside is the animation (really hated Ritsuko's character design) but theplot makes up for it, also the ending is so satisfying (if you don't feel satisfied enough, go read the manga for a few extra chapters). Overall it's definitely worth a watch and I recommend you to watch this anime.

Watched this cuz of Watanabe and tbh the sound blew me away. This man is a genius when it comes to picking the sounds he wants to go with this shows. The animation was good , but the CGI during the scenes where they play instruments was pretty good for that day and age. The story was mediocre. The characters were fine, the voice acting was ehhh. This show needs to be watched only for the sound. The animation was lacking in some places. Some scenes were downright cringy, also sometimes the story was too bloated and was pretty hard to follow the story. Somescenes were added to just increase running time.

Having a friend must be one of the greatest feelings ever, even better if he or she becomes a close one. You want to do everything together, from watching movies to playing card games, it's a whole lot of fun. Now, after a day well spent with that best friend of yours, you go back home and start reflecting: How did you two first meet? How will this friendship end?
Ladies and gentlemen, I am honoured to say that Sakamichi no Apollon, or Kids on the Slope, is one of my favourite music animes to date. A lot of people wonder whether this show is aboutthe friendship of the main two males of the story, Kaoru and Sentarou, or the romance of the main couple, Kaoru and Ritsuko. To be honest, I don't know and I don't care either. Both themes play a huge role in making this anime as beautiful as it is.


Let's break it down, shall we?


Story: 7/10

I wouldn't say the story was flawless, it did have its weak points here and there. But overall, they did a pretty good job on the plot for this anime. As a music anime, I agree that this show didn't have much of a focus on Jazz, but it still played an important role in bringing the characters together. What happened from there drifted more to romance, friendship and slice of life. In my opinion, I accepted that shift in genres but it could be just my lack of interest in jazz music.


Let's talk a bit about the romance in this story. It is very typical and cliche, with the main character falling in love with a girl who didn't know about her own feelings then. It felt flat, but I was anxious to see how it would develop from there. And I was not let down at all. With the sudden appearance of Yurika, whom Sentarou falls in love with, the plot immediately improved. Love triangles formed here and there and the characters begin questioning their love for one another. More characters showed up, creating a more complicated and interesting story overall. The show clearly nailed it.


Towards the end of the series, the show started to slowly drift back to the music genre. Friendships fall, gets rebuilt again and mass chaos happens here and there in terms of their emotions for each other. Those conflicts kept the story interesting and worthwhile to watch. The pre-ending was not rushed at all, the pace was smooth and understandable. And the ending was just heartwarming and delightful. Overall, I enjoyed the story and the only problem I saw here was the lack of focus on music. That's all, no biggie.


Art: 9/10

The art was beautiful. The way the characters moved, the landscape and their facial expressions, they nailed it. The amount of effort put into the anime to make it feel realistic is really underappreciated. I just felt uncomfortable at the fact that Ritsuko resembled a guy, in a certain way. If that's fixed, the art is flawless.


Sound: 8/10

Every anime needs a good opening that can reel in the viewer's interest, and part of it comes from the song. Kids on the Slope had a beautiful opening song, "Sakamichi no Melody" or "Melody of the Slope". It had no connection whatsoever to Jazz, which I'm sure disappointed many, but I enjoyed it nonetheless. It had a heartwarming and delightful feel to it, and the climax of the song illustrated how fast time flies when you're with someone you enjoy being with. I'm sure that was what they were going for. Altair, the ending, was slow and had a melancholic feel to it, which was perfect for the ending of the whole series. Once again, not much connection to Jazz, but I still enjoyed it.


Character: 8/10

The characters seemed very boring and typical at first glance. Kaoru, a nerd. Sentarou, a bully. Ritsuko, the cutie. It just felt flat, but as the series progressed, I witnessed the development of the characters as well. No character was stuck with one personality for the rest of the series. Kaoru had a rough side that makes him easily pissed, Sentarou had a soft side that makes him caring at times, Ritsuko has a sensitive side hidden under that delightful smile. Characters that seemed good at first glance suddenly turn against each other and you start to see their true colours. Sakamichi no Apollon nailed the character development, and I loved it.


Enjoyment: 10/10

As you have probably realised, I love this anime. All its up and downs, all its flaws and all its beauty, it burns deeply in my heart. From the start, I was hooked and I enjoyed watching them be together. The ending warmed my heart and broke it at the same time, realising that another outstanding show has ended. No one can truly understand what I feel about this anime without watching it, hence Wittgenstein's Beetle-In-A-Box analogy.


Overall: 9/10

Another great show ends, so you sit down and start thinking. The anime has impacted your life and you start noticing things about the friendship between you and your close friend, and you slowly begin to tie them together. How did both of you first meet? Was it as dramatic as Kaoru sliding off a white sheet, meeting Sentarou asleep on a couch beside the rooftop of the school? How did you want your friendship to end? Do you want it dramatic and happy, just like how this show ended? Now you realise what you want in this friendship, now it's up to you to create a bond with a friend that could last forever.


And hence, I rest my case.

Some light spoilers~
    The melody is, tu-tu-tuuuuuu tu-tu-tuuuuuuu, a lot like love.
That there is a single line from the opening song of ‘Kids on the Slope’ (‘Sakamichi no Apollon’ in Japanese) titled ‘Sakamichi no Melody’ performed by YUKI. The moment the female singer passionately chirped out, “Melody wa~” which was followed by a mighty trumpet, I knew that Sakamichi could very well be a memorable ride. I had goosebumps. A welcome sign, yes.
I first came across Sakamichi while bingeing DemolitionD’s ‘Should You Watch’ review series on YouTube. His review of Sakamichi was pretty damn hilarious. The 4 minutes video had 2 minutesdedicated to Demo’s classic antics. That was more than a year ago. So, when I watched Sakamichi recently and then hit Demo’s review again, I was surprised how much I did not remember. Thus, you can exhale a breath of relief that this review is not biased.


The point about bias is quite important, actually. Sakamichi is directed by Shinichiro Watanabe who was also behind such influential works as ‘Cowboy Bebop’ and ‘Samurai Champloo’. Except for the befuddling mess that was ‘Terror in Resonance’, many people simply guffaw over Watanabe’s works upon hearing his name. Personally, I found Cowboy Bebop to be just average while I consider Samurai Champloo to be one of my favorite anime. Space Dandy was pretty damn fun as well. As for Sakamichi…


I’ll kick off the review by saying that Sakamichi has to be Watanabe’s second best work. It’s not at the level of Samurai Champloo, which is in a class of its own, but it will still manage to leave a strong impression on most viewers – regardless of whether they like Jazz or not.


I myself am not heavily into Jazz (nor any particular genre for that matter) but I do still appreciate good music. Sakamichi’s use of, what I assume is, classic Jazz cements the base firmly for the plot to easily get into the SWING of things. And, that, it does.


Sakamichi’s plot is actually quite simple. Cliches and tropes are a-plenty. That doesn’t devalue nor demean the show’s story. Cliches and tropes exist for a reason and that reason is that they work. They are things you just can’t simply throw out of the window just like our main boy character did with the other male lead when he came into his room at night for some sweet boy-loving. Going for a stupid and plot-hole inducing twist in order to seem ‘fresh’ instead of executing tried ideas to perfection is just outright silly, in my opinion. An example would be Angel Beat’s final reveal. It just came completely out of nowhere and brought up a whole series of questions that it did not even attempt to answer even by foreshadowing or whatever. No, ‘Randy Orton: the Anime’, you can fuck off and so can my tears.


Anyway, the story starts off with classical pianist and socially anxious Kaoru transferring to a highschool in Kyushu where he somehow befriends the local thug-with-a-heart Sentarou using the power of Jazz. As the narrative pushes forward, you find the usual teenage melodrama accompanying the adventures the teens experience over the course of 2 years in the 1960s. There’s lots of drama – most of which is caused by the usual buffoonery of our Kaoru almost always blowing things as much out of proportion as a horndog with his very first blow-up sex doll. This is all supported with excellent musical performances by the cast. The music doesn’t take center stage nor is it made to stand out on the curb in a ‘Top Cat’ costume.


The story is predictable, of course. It’s a teenage romantic drama. There’s only so much you can do with that certain mix of genres. Thankfully, Sakamichi wonderfully makes use of its setting to expand on it as a whole. The anime feels like a misunderstood kouhai wanting to be noticed by their senpai and managing to succeed at that goal.


This is not to say that Sakamichi achieves this task flawlessly. The pacing may sometimes drag and sometimes it will jump around much too quickly. This is especially evident with the scenes that concern Jun, Sentarou’s neighbor, and Yukari, Sentarou’s crush. While the scenes deal with a much more serious romantic endeavor, what with Yukari still being in highschool and Jun being a college dropout disowned by his family, they progress faster than the very first episode of ‘Tonari no Kaibutsu-kun’ (there’s a confession and kiss in there). Maybe an extra episode could have helped. Or they could have removed some of Kaoru’s idiocy.


Another not-so-perfect point in regards to Sakamichi’s plot is the ending. It’s just meh. I was all smiles while I was watching it. Then, when I spent the next couple of minutes pondering it over I realized that it wasn’t as special as I initially had thought. Certainly, the very last moment was an absolute oomph when the opening song played to conclude the Jazzy ride but the few scenes before THAT didn’t have weight behind them. Goosebumps be damned! Sakamichi could have been better but it copped out with what I assume the director and writer(s) must have thought to be a true-to-life, and so, bittersweet ending.


Speaking of bittersweet, I am hungry and, thus, I must end this review. So, onto the technical stuff!


MAPPA and Tezuka Productions have done an excellent job overall. The animation is standard. The CGI doesn’t suck arse. It’s actually quite fluid. The decision to use such a coloring technique that it nearly matches the gradients of colors of the CGI was a smart move. The character designs are quite expressive as well. When matched with on-point voice actors, the big picture comes together quite nicely.


I’ve already gone into the Jazz specifics. Enthusiasts may recognize the names and works of Billy Evans and Chet Baker. The background music is alright. Suits the show. The opening and ending songs are fantastic. They build on the character of the anime. As I usually say, “Into the music folder they go,” and that they shall.


All things considered, Sakamichi scores an 8.5/10 from me (rounded off to 9 for MAL). With some refinement, it could have easily being a 10/10 show but it just kind of lost steam towards the end. It also momentarily touched on some rather mature topics such as racism and economical divide but it didn’t use them as junctions where it could find footholds with which to climb higher. Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend Kids on the Slope. You might either really like it or just find it dull if limited melodrama doesn’t amuse you.

For starters, if you were never introduced to the Jazz style of music, this anime will pump your veins full of hard hitting, fast paced, funky jazz, and the best part is.. you may just get hooked.  Not only is the music smooth and funky, but the main characters are extraordinarily lively.
The story is centered around a young lad in high school who is supposedly at the top of his class.  It is said that he studies hard and all of the other classmates envy him and in turn, hate him.  He isn't very social with anyone and life goes on, untillater into the first day of school.  The main character becomes nauseated and runs to the rooftop of the building where he can relax, except that he runs into bullies before reaching the top.  Here is where the first supporting character comes in. I won't spoil the rest.


The second and final supporting character keeps the peace between the two, but later down the line causes twists in the plot line.


This anime is about true companionship and leaves a warm, if not fired up, feeling in your heart, even through the hardships happening around the characters.


Okay, we'll begin with the ratings:

Story - 10 - This is the first time that I have marked a slice of life genre with a ten.  I was consistently enthralled to continue the story just find out what else is happening in this ordinary life. I mean, does anybody actually say that?  

Graphics - 8 - Very well done.  Nothing to blow the mind like "Ahh, that was sooo amazing!" or "Woah, I forgot to breathe", but I can say that they were well crafted.

Sound - 10 - I never truly understand Jazz until I watched this anime.  Now, I can say that a piece of me is addicted to this new sound.

Characters - 10 - The reasons for the actions of each the main character and two supporting characters are explained through the anime. These three characters are so LIVELY in terms of emotions and motives.


Overall - 10 - Very, very cool slice of life anime.  I even took the extra time to lookup songs from the genre and download to my phone.

Recommended: It's quite possible that others will not see this anime as a ten, but this is definitely not an anime that will leave anyone disappointed. The crowd score at this moment in time is around 8.50.  I highly recommend.


IceMasterCho out!

Another unexpected Josei anime that I didn't notice. So.. music and drama.. Yeah,  Shigatsu wa kimi no Uso has some similarities to this series but don't worry, no deaths here... or was there one? Huehuehuehue... Yeah just find out for yourself but don't push so much and hate on me for that. 
Anyways, I guess the plot was unique and very well blended into the story. The Drama based slice of life resembles other series with the same genres. This series was a bit older than Shigatsu so I don't think anyone copied either. Since the setting was in the late 1960's, it wasthe era which Jazz music was popular and classic Rock was about to be born. The place it centered around was a countryside with simple lifestyles showcased by the characters. Though the series was musically centered, it was well balanced by the other genres it was tagged for.The art is decent for a series with its age and most backgrounds are well detailed. The characters may have unique traits but atleast they show real feelings unlike fiction only emotions during different situations. The character development is on point and maybe a bit unexpected sometimes. I didn't enjoy this series very much because I cringe at awkward romance situations and I can't stand to watch those events. I appreciate that the series used real songs and brands for the props of the story. Though I am someone who is into rock and metal, I appreciated Jazz music from this series and it piqued my interest in this genre of music. So this anime being centered around that wasn't really that bad. \n\n
I gave this anime an excellent rating because it has shown the things that I want to see and what the author and producers wanted the audience to see from this series that they have created. It does not need a sequel because it was given enough closure in the end. I recommend this to viewers who want to explore the unique beat of Jazz Music.

I usually go nuts for this sort of thing. 1950s/60s Japanese setting (flashbacks of Kurosawa) with a focus on character and setting with coming-of-age drama and the connections formed by music predominating, all mixed together with beautiful Studio Ghibli-esque animation and directed by the guy who did Cowboy Bebop. But something about it just never clicked for me. Maybe it's the jazz focus (I've never really been a jazz fan) but I think it's more the lack of any structure or satisfying resolution. Not that the ending is bad. Actually, the concluding section is near perfect. It's just that nothing builds up to anything andin the end all the characters seem to be drifting aimlessly. Maybe that's the point? I don't know. All I know is that it had lost my attention by about episode eight and the last few episodes were a real struggle to get through.\n\n
It also bothered me that the character motivations seem so incomprehensible. That's a typical Japanese thing, particularly in the mid-20th century and earlier, but just because a piece is set in a time doesn't mean it has to be obtuse. I'm reminded of my least favorite Kurasawa film, The Quiet Duel, in which a doctor contracts syphillis when operating on a wounded soldier and spends the rest of the film heroically not saying anything about it to his fiance (who he can now never marry) or anyone else since he cannot bear to live with the apparently impossible shame. Yeah, it doesn't make any sense to me either. And the characters here act like that. Shame prevents them from doing absolutely anything (although it doesn't extend to performing publically, oddly, the one area where that makes total sense to me) and even when all sides know something nobody is ever willing to talk about it. And really, I didn't understand the reasons behind half of what the lead does.

I have never written an anime review before but I had to after just finishing this one. do not watch this anime because you WILL feel too much emotion, I mean I literally didn't think I would feel like this after watching it but it pulled on all of my emotional strings. It made me laugh, cry, yell, rejoice then repeat all of that again and I'm not one to easily feel that for a show but this was so good, sometimes I wanted to reach into the screen and help/talk/jam with them. This is a really good anime with a simple and beautiful storythat will make you care about almost every charecter that is on screen. the only problem I have with this anime is that I want more, I feel like its so much left unsaid and the ending will make you want to be a fly on the wall in the room when the 3 main characters meet up, I find myself a little envious that I don't know these characters and that ill probably never get to hear from them again but what they gave me was incredible and memorable and I hope they are living their best life. Oh and it goes without saying the art work and music in this anime is phenomenal with the characters love of jazz music and how it effects them and the story. 9/10 would Highly recommend and watch again.

An anime that i feel appreciate jazz in many ways atleast thats how i feel as i relax and watch it but with its bumps its not all rosy as i watch this. 
The story is well created its not typical and since it focus on an earlier time and place when everything was different i would say that brings out something unique in that regards. This is best examplified with how some people behave or act since remember this anime is set in an older time there people had less choices in their life. I have two minds about this story as i havewatched this anime. On one hand i have the feelings of loving the flow but , on the other hand i only like the flow to a certain point in the anime. After the introduction episodes were done there we found out about most characters i felt they tried to pack too much drama into it and it became staggering how much you felt the story stopped and flowed as one watched it. It was kinda like a crack in a record that just kept staggering. And this is kinda why for me the anime at a point took what i felt was a melodramatic turn until it slowed and went into a nice pace again of a sort. 


As with many musical anime its no wonder that in this case the music takes the highest marks because this anime gives from what i feel a great representation of jazz. Although there can always be more its a nice that there is an anime that manage to capture and make people like the genre just from having watched an anime. 


So in this anime there is 3 main character which i can try to summarise my thoughts about. 

Kawabuchi, Sentarou who is the typical delinquent who gets into fights with random people and is mostly feard by many due to his strenght. Hes a nice enough and likeable character in itself but he also is the typical dense character who doesnt realise how he feels many times and has to be told by his friend who has to try to steer him the right way. That dense character can sometimes get too much as with any character with that trait. 


Nishimi, Kaoru is an introverted boy who has had to move alot around when he was young. Due to this he is made into at first being the typical boy who gets pushed into taking the mantle from his family and do what they/his aunt tell him to. Feels like a pushover but has a really outgoing personality and is fun to follow as you watch the anime and gets to know his thoughts and feelings. Although i would say in his case his drama can sometimes gets too much and it starts to get irritating. 


Mukae, Ritsuko is a female who feels very much like the shy yet lovable character who one almost feel is a supportive one but as you move through the story one sees her as a true main and learn to feel with her or get irritated over her depending on your feelings. 


I enjoyed this anime alot although there were things i wished could have been done better i really enjoyed how most of it went. I would recommend this anime to most people although some might say that the beginning is slow or that a character seems a little too boring and doesnt show enough i can almost promise that it will get better. Its great for those who want to enjoy music with a good story combined with some interesting characters that you will enjoy in your own ways. 


Although i might praise it alot more i still feel that this anime for me is an 8. Why because i feel that it was being too dramatic for my taste. There was a certain point in it there i felt there was a good balance between the two but as the anime went further it went more and more on the melodrama and it annoyed me that i rarely got a moment to just enjoy the anime and music it had.

It's my first review, so, please don't be too strict. (Beforehand, I'd like to apologize for all mistakes that I could overlook m(_ _)m)
Ok, here we go...
Story: 9/10
"Reminds me of "Beck"- that was my first thought after the first episode. "Nope, it's closer to "Honey and clover"- was my thought after the second episode.Right now, I don't actually care about this anymore.
Basic things: 'school','friendship','love','joint interest'. It should seem to be nothing new. Then what's so great about it? Why do I continue to watch it? Sincere realistic story. I think that's the main point. It should seem, ordinary, even stereotypical thing, yet..it looks real. Rightnow, though I've watched only 10 episodes and I don't know where this story will go. I've got a feeling that it actually could have happened. It's hard to say what exactly makes me think like this..Who knows. But the fact that I do believe in it, makes this anime brilliant in my eyes.    \n
Art: 7/10\n
Soft colours deepen the 'retro' atmosphere. Characters look not too realistic nor too embellish. Hm.. reminds me of 'Paradise Kiss', 'Baccano' and 'Beck'.\n
Sound: 8/10\n
Jazz..should I add something? If you're not a fan of it, this anime will make you like it :)\n
Character: 8/10\n
What I really like about them, that they seems to be real. Just normal girls and boys.\n
(Accent makes them even more adorable)\n
Enjoyment: 9/10\n
Like listening to a retro record...It brings some thoughts about past and present. Was it better back than? Maybe nothing has changed..or maybe... \n
Sad thoughts, pleasant thoughts. Like a jazz music, this anime will relax you and make your calm mind just drift on the waves.

In just 12 episodes, Kids on the Slope ease our hearts by giving us a mental break of any stress we are surround at the moment: it remind us the beauty of the now (more in our fast paced era). A story of self-encounter, growing-up with maturity (without the influence of to much 'reality tv' that has create a generation full of unnecessary drama), and the reality that extraordinary things lies in the ordinary. As always, Watanabe sensei just delivers! Highly recommended!

Kids On the Slope is a solid piece of work, but it pales in comparison with other works of the same or similar genres. What's wrong with it in my opinion? It feels unnatural. 
In other words, the progression of events and the interaction of characters make me feel like they are what they are for the sake of the storyline and overall atmosphere. It's like, you first create an unchangeable backdrop and lot of things to be done and then make some characters fit in some roles to do those things. I didn't feel any deeper traits that actually defined each character, so consequently,whether or not the characters are what they are doesnt really matter to the story anymore, since the story would nevertheless progress the way it was written. This type of progression might work fine for horror or mystery, but definitely not for drama or slice of life. I believe that the importance of each characters foremost must surpass the importance of the storyline in order for a drama to be successful. Otherwise, there is no point in watching it since it would be too trivial. 


Another thing about this series is that the story lacks anything that pops. You can say that's the way Josie series are. However, for me this can only mean the Josie genre needs a breakthrough. Anyways, for me, no matter you use which genre to define this show, it doesn't live up to the potential in any of the genres. 


However, it is a solid piece of work. From the music to the animation, there is nothing one can really complain about. The big picture is perfect, but too perfect for the characters to shine through. That's why I couldn't bring myself to like it as much as I wanted to.

Sakamichi no Apollon, in my opinion, was a great anime. The animation is what dragged me in. Usually I don't like reading the synopsis because I like "surprises". I watched both the subbed and the dubbed and the voice acting was amazing. 
Kaoru and Sentaro had amazing backgrounds which made them seem like total opposites. Kaoru is a rich and smart kid with no place in his home and has a liking to classical music at first. Sen on the other hand is a poor kid and bad student with a really sad background which makes him have no place in society so he takesout his frustration through fighting and jazz music. Both of them are outsiders which make them become closer. Its a slice of life which means expect it to pull on your heart strings. 

------------------

SPOILERS:


My least favorite character was Ritsuko since she rejected Kaoru's feelings  after he kissed her since she liked Sen and then a year later she starts liking Kaoru. Although their relationship goes nowhere which is a real bummer cause I was looking forward to more development in that. Brother Jun and Yurika had an amazing relationship together which made up for it. 


I especially liked how it didn't end with a "What happened to Sen?" Ending. It's rare to find anime series which go +8 years Into the future to show how each of the characters have developed in their lives.

---------------


Overall, Sakamichi no Appollon had an outstanding animation, amazing dub and sub, good characters, and great music which added to the anime. I'd recommend to watch it.

I'll keep this review short...
I never hated jazz, but I was never a fan. This series awoke some hidden joy in me. 
Sakamichi no Apollon doesn't have THE BEST JAZZ EVER, but the music in this series is a gift to us all. 
The story is also compelling. The pacing is really well done and over all the series manages to be both suspenseful and relaxing (I kid you not).
If you watch this series through, you are in for quite the ride!
I'm trying to think of what I hated about this story, but most of the complaints I had when I started it were gonewhen I reached the end. \n\n
Bitter sweet and precious, "Kids on the Slope" does a good job on telling a story that not only tugs on the heart strings, but also seems realistic.

Kids on the slope! a true heart-warming and faith-strengthening experience.
Behold, my ratings! 
Story: 5-6
Art: 8
Sound: 8
Character: 7
Enjoyment: 8
Overall:7-8
"These are a few of my favorite things!"
Sakamichi No Apollon delivered in the enjoyment category no doubt. That late 1960's vibe, combined with the animation and music of the show, and lively characters..all of it was simple, yet effective and satisfying. Sentaro was my go-to watch character in the series, just because his story and appearance, and his attitude, and he was christian. Richie and him went great together in the whole series, it felt..right and necessary having them around each other, because the anime felt interesting wheneverthey would meet up. Just those two making music, filled KOTS duties on music. Of course let's not forget the other musicians. \n\n
The other characters weren't too important aside from Ritsu. Junichi's scenes and involvement were good, but really...man all I wanted to see is if when am I going to see more jazz being made! Richie and Sentaro, without them getting screen time together the show would be probably bad! Those two characters go hand-in-hand, because they created lots of entertainment for me. The last episode..oh man it was fantastic, a great ending indeed (you won't be disappointed!)\n\n
As for the rest of the story, some parts feel extremely rushed..and those specific parts I felt would've been essential to make the story more interesting and to get to know the characters way more. The story isn't special at all aside from the heart-warming and tear-jerking ending. I never understood Richie, he was so surprising and so interesting in the beginning of the series, however later on, he gets confusing. I never got to know much about him aside from his few interests. Again, this story is laughable and probably mediocre, simple but nothing much to talk about, although the ending justified it for me.\n\n
As for music..I went ahead and downloaded the ost. You will most likely be to do so as well if your into Yoko Kanno's stuff. I watched the OP every episode. Special effects were close to none at all including atmospheric effects, car noises, birds chirping, wind blowing, none of that organic stuff. Voice acting was good, I liked it alot! Background music fitted in so well with so many of the scenes as I could remember, some of them were really feel-good and just nice to have an ear on!\n\n\n
I'll end this review here. I want to recommend you to watch this anime, even though there's a tiny chance you won't like it..but it's only 12 episodes of music, drama, and romance. ALso, I just wanna say this anime made me cry like buckets. Just do yourself a favor and watch Sakamichi No Apollon, it won't hurt. If you like enlightening and heart-warming stuff, watch this anime!\n\n
Thanks for reading!\n\n
May grace and peace be with you, and God bless you. :)

Kids on the Slope follows Kaoru a boy who starts at a new school he is used to going from school to school because of his dads work he doesn't get a long with people in his classes due to always moving to new schools and being rich. The first day of school was really tough for him but he asks where the roof of the school is on his way up he sees this sheet put over a bench this is where he first meets Sentarou and his high school life changes. He goes on to becoming friends with this boy after he giveshim keys to the roof and follows him around. Sentarou is someone who gets into a lot of trouble due to his enjoyment of fighting so Kaoru is very unsure about him. He finds out Ritsuko the class rep is childhood friends with him. They end up all becoming friends with the power of music Sentarou plays the drums and loves jazz music so Kaoru being a piano player wants to impress him by learning jazz. Throughout this series there are a lot of huge things that lead up to Ritsuko and Kaoru winding up together. This series was honestly so heart warming I love this anime because of all the fantastic music in this anime and the heart warming love story of two friends and there hardships of getting each other to fall in love. I honestly find this series so appealing with its simplistic art style, great story, and great character back story.

Ok this is my first time writing a review, so it's probably going to be quite short, but this anime gave me too many feels I just have to review it.
Story: 10/10
Why 10? To me, it's not the actual plot itself, but the way it is presented that's perfect. I'm not sure how to phrase it properly, but the way the story flows is very natural. It doesn't take any big dramatic event to make it develop, it's just that episode by episode you get dragged into it naturally. 
Art: 9/10
I've read reviews before I finally decided to watch this anime, but the art iswhat mainly attracted me.

Simple art style but beautiful lighting, and not to forget, the way the animation was done. Unlike some animes, motion and movements in this anime are done incredibly well, especially movements like drumming and playing the piano. It made me actually feel like it was real, that the characters were drumming and playing piano, instead of real people who did the job for these sounds.

One thing that bugged me a little though, was the fact that girls had a jawline like a guy's, it decreased the femininity. This is the reason why I gave the art a 9 and not a 10.


Sound: 9/10

For a person like me who has never really listened to Jazz before, I actually quite enjoyed the music. The songs were catchy and actually 'Moanin' is still stuck in my head.


Character: 10/10

The best freaking part. The characters are the most outstanding thing of this anime, emphasizing Kaoru and Sentarou. If I were forced to choose one of these two, I can't, because to me they're both equally awesome. They both have a soft and strong side. What's very interesting is that the physically strongest one (Sentarou) isn't always the protector. He has his weak moments and Kaoru is always the one taking initiative and clearing Sen's thoughts at the right time. I'm kind of bad at describing such things but if you watch the anime you will understand.  


Enjoyment: 9/10

I finished this anime in two days but I would have finished it in one day if I wasn't occupied with school. I enjoyed this anime a hell lot and I honestly wish I'd have watched it earlier. The only thing that didn't please me was the ending. I don't like the way it was ended and the fact that some things weren't explained and elaborated. But that's just my opinion.


Overall: 10/10

Despite the somewhat 'meh' ending, I'd say overall this anime is a masterpiece. To me it definitely is. I would recommend this anime to anyone, even people who aren't into Jazz. Feel free to give it a shot. Trust me, you won't regret it.

"Sometimes life is like jazz and moves in an unexpected direction."
This one line from this anime sums up this series well, especially in terms of its story and characters. One thing the synopsis doesn't tell you is that this anime is about learning to be open to new experiences, because life doesn't always go up or down or in a circle.
The character that best embodies this lesson is Kaoru Nishimi, who is one of the main characters and the main focus of this anime. Before he meets Sentarou (a tough, imposing male) and Ritsuko (Sentarou's female childhood friend), Kaoru is an intelligent stiff with socialanxiety issues so bad that he feels ill when he feels stressed about interacting with others. Kaoru encloses himself in a metaphorical circle and walks through life with a metaphorical "down" perspective that he gradually comes out of as the series progresses and he learns to play jazz.


Sentarou and Ritsuko embody unexpected directions because of the impact they have on Kaoru and because they aren't what you expect, especially from reading the anime's synopsis. If you have any doubts about this, I recommend watching the first four episodes before you decide to drop this. 


The most touching thing about the complexity of Sentarou and Ritsuko is that with Kaoru, they form a deep bond that is like a family. Even when those three are in a love triangle, the familial bond is still there. Despite their romantic feelings, Sentarou is like a elder brother, Ritsuko is like a sister in the middle, and Kaoru is like the youngest brother. This familal bond that causes them to try not to hurt each other and feel remorseful when they do end up doing so.


Besides the characters, the soundtrack is incredible. Composed by Yoko Kanno, the jazz music provides an atmosphere similar to that in Cowboy Bebop, except this jazz isn't bebop. It's relaxing stuff in the vein of John Coltrane (whose work is featured a bit in this anime btw), except during action scenes (which are scored just as well as the stuff from Cowboy Bebop). I downloaded half the soundtrack after watching just the 1st episode, b/c I knew Yoko Kanno would make it great.


The next-to-last notable thing in this anime is the setting. Since it is set in the sixties, a bit of historical and cultural stuff is sprinkled throughout the anime, such as racism, the popularity of rock n' roll (esp. The Beatles), and political student protests. This added depth to the characters' world and made things more interesting for them at times.


Finally, the last notable thing in this anime are little details (probably provided by Cowboy Bebop director Shinichiro Wantabe) such as the episode titles being named after jazz songs, the early love confessions (thank you for not occurring at the very end) and the way music ties the three main characters just as much as their drama.


I've only seen two other music-centered josei anime (NANA and two seasons of Nodame Cantabile), but this one has become my favorite one (sorry NANA). If NANA is the best josei anime with post college grads, then Kids on The Slope is the best josei anime with high school students.

Oh my God!!!!This anime had the power to make me burn inside wishing to write a review.It's just as good as that.
I have been thinking for a long time that anime these days cannot realy be at the same level as old creations, but this one proved me the opposite.Now let's analyse its good points.

Another thing that a want to point out is the way it ends.Generally you feel kind of dissapointed if it's smth cheesy.or easy to anticipate but it won't happen with this one.
