To start off, finding an anime series like this hardly happens.  There is a very small majority of anime that has jazz music, slice of life, and school genres included.  Sakamichi no Apollon is one of those gems that hardly comes along in anime.  Since it is directed by Shinichirō Watanabe, you know it's gonna be be good.  So, I'll begin with the story.  In a nutshell, our protagonist Kaoru Nishimi has been transferred to a school.  He finds our major secondary character  Sentarō Kawabuchi and spark a really bromantic relationship.  They then start jazzsessions at Ritsuko Mukae's, who is also a major character, session room.  To let you know, if you can tolerate episodic episodes here and there and pacing shifts then you should be good.  If you can't, well try anyway.  The story is original which also makes the story twist and turn.  Also, there is... about 2 love triangles and some awkward social moments too that will make you cringe.  All in all, story deserves a 9.  The art is amazing.  If you have watched Honey and Clover, which I strongly recommend you do, you'll find there are similarities.  Though it is uncommon, there are times when it fails. So, I give the art a 10.  The sound is not for everyone.  I love jazz, but it is really uncommon to find other people who do.  If you don't, don't watch it, because it is very heavily influenced by jazz.  If you have watched Baccano! or Cowboy Bebop you shouldn't have a problem.   After all, it is composed by Yoko Kanno. I give the sound a 9.  I'm not gonna get deep into the characters, because there is a lot.  Each one is unique and are probably one of the most realistic anime characters I have experienced.  Like I said previously, there are 2 love triangles.  If you can't deal with unrequited love and awkward social moments, your cringe meter is gonna go off the charts.  I give the characters a 9.  I would give it an overall rating of 10, but that's my personal enjoyment, so I give it a 9.

There is only one word to describe this anime with.. Beautiful! The story ,the art ,the music and the way they express themselves through it , the love ..just everything. I was having high doubts about starting this ,but the only thing I doubt now is not starting this any sooner. The character development is amazing. There wasn't a single character without a purpose. When their happy ,I'm happy. When their sad ,I can't help but feel sad too. It brought up all the emotions in me and I am so sad that it ended. Sakamichi no Apollon has become one of my recentfavourite anime. I honestly can't see how anyone would not like that  even though it's a Josei (aimed for older female audience). This anime is amazing and I can not recommend it enough. It deserves respect and it's one of those animes where you have to watch till the end to go back and appreciate the beginning. \n\n
10 out of 10 for all.

I wondered why the anime seemed oldy-worldy, didn't realize it was set in the 60's...
Hello guys, and welcome again to a Waldy565 review. I absoloutley LOVE music so decided to watch this series instead of my usual one-episode reviews, and at only 12 episodes there was really no point reviewing it from only one show!
Story - the story is, hmm, hard to judge. I may repeat myself a little when talking about the characters because they are linked (story and character that is). You can read the description yourself, but yeah, my score explains my thoughts!
Art - the art is really nice! It's not themost beautiful I've seen (then again, my favourite anime art is the CGI K-On/Love Live stuff, with hints of hand drawn stuff like You're Under Arrest and Cowboy Bebop) but I can't bash it either. It really complements the sound I think. Oh, speaking of which...\n\n
Sound - WOW! This won't please everyone, but anyone who has a slight whiff of a music connoisseur about them will appreciate the musical score of the anime. I said the art complemented the sound, and what I mean by this is Jazz had it's high and low moments. However, personally, the jazz in this is all-high, no-low. Perfect, not has a soundtrack enticed me since K-On! (and Cowboy BeBop, Code Geass and Love Live before it)\n\n
Character - I really, really like the characters. Many of them portray the "under-dog" figure, and you root for them whenever they struggle. I myself "jam" with my mates, we're not a band as such, so I can relate to the aspect of the four people being part of a band. I think what it is is they are relatable and show real, HUMAN emotion(s), and it makes them all the more enjoyable!\n\n
Enjoyment/Overall - If you enjoy music, Jazz-especially, and want to enjoy an anime that has a not-so-rememrable story but interesting characters, I'd definetley give this a look into! However, don't like music-based anime? This ain't gonna change your mind...

The story is overall decent, i mean, personally i dont really see how i could make an unforgettable story out of a jazz theme in this era of anime anyways.
Considering it was released somewhere around 2012-2013, the art is decent, nothing breathtaking or disgusting.
Obviously since its a "music" anime, it should have a great OST. It wasn't a Hall of Fame soundtrack in any way, but the music really just fits the characters and the anime as a whole. Good job
The characters are pretty good, different personalities, unpredictable, and great job on this. Their personalities clash well with each other forming the decent story italked about in the first paragraph.\n\n
I enjoyed it. Simple. There's not a lot of anime i can find that's good, as I barely have time to go on the hunt for some.

Kids on the Slope is one of the more under rated music animes I have seen and I think that is a real shame. The creator of Kids on Slope is the same man behind Space Dandy, Samurai Champloo, and Cowboy Bebop. So if you enjoyed any of those shows I recommend Kids on the Slope.The story does have some cliches but I feel the pacing is fast enough and the relationships between the characters are believable enough that the cliches are not much of an issue. Kids on the Slope can be an endearing story of friendship and actually has a pretty well writtenromantic subplot.\n
Of Course the real appeal of Kids on the Slope is the awesome jazz soundtrack and the gorgeous animation. The same person who did the music for Cowboy Bebop, which had one of the most amazing soundtracks in all of anime, also did the soundtrack for Kids on the Slope. It is any jazz lover's dream come true. The animation for all of the music scenes is incredible. The motion of the characters playing their instruments is so realistic, detailed, and smooth that it looks like it could have been live action footage that the animators just drew over. And I played the drums for a couple years.\n
Kids on the Slope is a must watch for any anime fans that like jazz, and I strongly recommend to fans of musical anime.

If anime could embody the experience that an individual goes through when playing or listening to jazz this would be that anime. As a jazz musician myself, I see this show as being incredibly accurate to the art and how it's portrayed to the community. From the jump, the story is built upon with background information to supply the viewer with a stable understanding of the protagonist and his ventures. The interaction between characters is nothing short of intimate which helps the overall pull of the shows content, although the characters can be a bit over dramatic at times. Besides that the music, scenery, artstyle, acting, and plot are amongst the best in my opinion. For any music lover out there who wants a good story to go with it, this is an absolute must.

I'll say I don't particularly like giving out good scores. If I find an issue with a series characters, story, progression, animation, themes, etc. I try my hardest to think critically and explore why such issues exist--and ways an anime could've done better.
STORY- (9/10) GREAT
I know, my opening sentence may contradict that first review score, but the thing is the story is handled exceptionally well. If there was one issue I could note is that at the beginning of the story the main character has some sort of condition that seemed to have been caused by some childhood psychological issues, and its quickly resolved bytime he meets one of the other main cast members (which there are three) and not mentioned or brought up again throughout the rest of the story. I dislike that. If you're going to introduce an aspect about a character during the first episode, that defines who they are--don't simply disregard that because it would drive focus away from introducing other characters and plot elements. 


With that being said, that was the only noticeable aspect. This is included in the story portion because had the main character been affected by his "condition" for longer than five minutes, the story's progression and direction would look drastically different than what was done instead. 


This anime does include jazz as a backdrop to the other leads, but unlike Your Lie in April, it is not the main focus. It is simply a means for the characters to come together. A catalyst for building their relationships if you will. The progression and pacing is adequate enough to get the viewer invested in the different arcs, and they all make logical sense. That's actually the part I like the most. These characters behave like teenagers. They encounter problems that in retrospect seem petty and easily solved, are impressionable about the opposite sex, and attempt to grow in personality. the arcs play out well and are realistic to the point where I could see this being based off similar events. 




ART (7/10) GOOD



The designs for the characters are tasteful and not overdone. None of the characters have outrageous hair designs, facial structures, or body compositions. The animation hits its high notes during the moments the characters are playing instruments, or there is a dramatic scene. Otherwise it is pretty standard across the board. This is an element I dislike. If they had animated the entire series the way they do when the characters are playing instruments, then the animation would've been more cohesive and consistent. To have exemplary animation in one scene, and return to standard animation in the next distances the viewer from the experience as a whole. It makes certain moments seem extra special while everything else is ordinary. Overall, since the standard animation was actually decent, the designs were consistent, backgrounds were interesting and fairly believable I would have to say the art is good but nothing special.



SOUND (8/10) VERY GOOD


I'll say this: I do not listen to jazz in my everyday experience. So I do not know what "Great jazz" sounds like. I've never been into  the genre because I simply can't follow the instruments that weave in and out of melodies, the tones, and the direction of the music, but I digress. When these characters play instruments, it is well done. The score they have chosen for instances outside of musical performances is tasteful and doesn't detract from the scene. Things are silent when they need to be, background score volume is increased or played subtlety according to the direction of the scene, and most importantly, the music choice is very simple. The thing about the jazz pieces in this anime was that they weren't complicated to where it would take years of practice to play efficiently, but intermediate pieces that someone whose hobby was playing instruments would be able to learn and get better at. 


Another aspect I found interesting is how the music actually played a part in developing the characters and story progression. For instance, the main character writes a song to play for the girl he has a crush on, later on in the story that same girl is startled when someone finds her humming that very song and uses that to initiate conversation. Very subtle techniques that make the score play apart of the story instead of being an afterthought.



CHARACTERS (9/10) GREAT





The main character has his shortcomings, as he is meant to represent the average smart teenager who moves into an unfamiliar place, but this is where the other two lead characters shine. The characters play well off one another and have actual conversations with one another that develop the story. The other characters play their part, and stay in it. They were driving forces for their particular arc, and after its conclusion they move on. The same characters don't tag along for the rest of the story, and so this helps the pacing. The characters all also have their own distinct personality that isn't simply based off of some weird trope. They do not change from one personality type to the other, but simply adapt in minor ways according to the plot progression. 




ENJOYMENT (10/10) OUTSTANDING



I watched this series in the span of three days, and so I may not have noticed some weird cutting off points between episodes but each episode served its purpose. There weren't any episodes devoted to filler, or an inconsequential event that had nothing to do with the over-arching story. Each event had its beginning, climax, and conclusion. The character progression was satisfying to watch unfold, and their behavior, reactions, and thoughts seemed very realistic. Some mistakes were made out of rash behavior, there were misunderstandings, but as the characters begin to learn more about each other and develop close relationships, these issues are resolved and the story doesn't backtrack. The pacing was done rather well, and the ending wasn't a "and they all lived happily ever after!" and not all of their problems are solved. 





OVERALL (9/10) GREAT



This was a very good romance show. It is one of the instances where the high school isn't the most important location for the story, but more of a natural place. The story progressed very well, and the sound played a factor in its pacing. The characters were likable and not over the top and so I ended up invested in the events of the series. Definitely worth a rewatch in my case, and in the case of a new viewer: definitely something worth checking out.

So many reviews have already said what I wanted to say, so I'll just add that as a musician who plays the piano and trumpet (and has done so for close to 20 years) I found this series to be some of the best television I've ever watched. The idea of music connecting people, the romance plot, the bromance plot, and so much else resonated with me on a very deep level that made my cry tears of joy and sadness. 
Yoko Kanno (of Cowboy Bebop fame) wrote and arranged the music for this and it is as spectacular as you could imagine. If youare a fan of jazz (or have an inkling that you could enjoy jazz) this will be a real treat for you.\n\n
Overall, this is one of the best series I've seen in a quite awhile and I recommend it to everyone wholeheartedly.

Episodes 1/2
Our stuck-up main character, Kaoru, has his life changed when he meets Sentaro, a loose, expressive man. For these kinds of stories, there isn't a "plot" because the characters are the plot, like in Catcher in the Rye. Kaoru's transformation is just awesome because it reflects my own hesitations, and it is depicted just too realistically, it made me laugh... like a half-laugh. However, one character development that hasn't been explored yet is Sentaro's. He's all expressive and stuff, but will he change? Will he learn to restrain himself, as Kaoru does? If this show is going to be the best that it canbe, Sentaro needs to change as well. But what doesn't need to change is the sound. Magnificent jazz! Background music? It's Yokko Kanno! On the other hand, the art and images are not afraid to make an atmosphere, which they do successfully... and it's unique. Awesome stuff. Watch it!

The story is not particularly explosive. However, the thing with coming of age or slice of life story is that, it’s the most relatable and authentic. The drama is something that any type of viewer can relate to. It can be boring at the beginning but that’s usually given with this kind of genre. The magic happens when an author is able to make a slice of life story interesting which in this case I believe is successful enough.
Almost all the characters have something to offer with the whole impact the story brings. Each of their personal issues makes the genre of the story moreeffective.


I am not a technical person but I still somehow can tell how nicely done the animation of the series is most particularly when the characters are playing. And let’s not forget the amazing sounds that the series has. Even the subs by the seiyuu’s are interesting and refreshing.


I’ve seen amazing series about classical music (Nodame Cantabile) and pop music (K-On!), so this time, jazz is added to my favorite list of anime about music. It’s about love, family, drama, music, and most importantly it’s about friendship. It’s really worth to watch.

Bill Evans starring as Richie Rich.
And here I thought that Jazz was dead. Huh, figures. 
Sakamichi no Apollon or Kids on the Slope, whichever you prefer, has music from Yoko Kanno (the same composer of the widely acclaimed Cowboy Bebop, I might add) and I think that gives a sufficient foothold to realize how good this anime is going to be.
Story:
7/10
Let's start with the show's weakest point (although not a mediocre one) the story. The story starts like this: Bill Evans, is your usual hard working, rich, academician and pianist protege, that has recently moved to the islands where he plans to attend a newschool. Bill Evans, a freshman in highschool meets Sentarou, which introduces him to the world of Jaaaaaaazzzzz, in which Bill Evans get's accustomed to. Apollon has a very linear way of storytelling. Nothing complex or compelling, but it's definitely  heartwarming and travels at an enticing pace to leave you wanting more. Keep in mind, I watched the series in one seating, so that's pretty good evidence on how good the pacing was. Unfortunately, the story was a bit cliche' and dried out due to the heavy romance that got nowhere in the end. The setting is also very unique. Not a lot of animes take place in the 40's.


Art:

8/10

I haven't seen a lot of music animes, but goddamn. Apollon's animation during the musical scenes are stupendously accurate! Seriously, I have no idea who was in charge with the main animation of Apollon, but damn is it good. The rest of the anime has standard animation, but the show's art really shines during the music scenes.


Sound:

10/10

ART BLAKEY!? BILL EVANS!? YOKO KANNO REMAKING THESE SONGS?

Seriously dude, what can I say about the music? It's free jazz, the best genre of music you'll find. Music is top notch, I just wished more of the show focused on the music, you know, considering it IS a music anime.


Characters:

9/10

Apollon's strongest suit (besides the music) was the characters. The 3 main characters: Ritsuko, Sentarou, and Bill Evans, are amazing. Like I said, Bill is your standard smart dude, that meets a guy which then introduces him to the world of Jazz. By far, my favorite character was Sentarou. Sentarou is like that intimidating guy you meet on the first day of high school, but then you get to know him and he ends up being a cool dude. Over the series, Bill and Sen develop a very friendly and likable relationship, they also have their ordeals... Ritsuko, the love interest, was a very sweet girl, she was very caring and supportive for the two. The best part of this series is the way it makes the main character grow into such a different person by the end, but I'll let you see that.


Enjoyment/Overall:

8/10

In conclusion, I was expecting a show heavy on music, whilst sacrificing plot and characters and instead got the best of three worlds. You can tell I enjoyed the series (considering I watched in one inning) so if you liked some of Yoko Kanno's previous works, then I can guarantee that you'll enjoy it.


TL;DR:

Yoko Kanno, man. Watch the show.

I have given this 10 across the score board.
This anime has really touched my heart. It has love, hate, and all the things you normally face in real life.
Koaru a quite kid is attending a new school. He studies and does his homework, he lives with his aunt and uncle. Everything is quite in his life until the school's so called thug comes into his life Sentarou (Sen). Sen saves Koaru from being bullied which causes them to drift closer as best friends. Sen introduces Koaru to Jazz and Ritsuko the daughter of the record store owner where they go to start to play music.Ritsuko is also Sen's childhood friend and Koaru fall's in love with her the first time he sees her. This is where it all starts which leads them to be the best friends.


It is not a fast paced anime but each episode makes you want to cry be it joy or sadness. This is like the life of some put into animation.


The last episode wraps it up perfectly and it is a satisfying ending. This is what animes used to be like before all the action and bloodshed scenes. 


Anyway love the anime, great job to the creators and keep it up.

Kaoru Nishimi, a relate-able character for some, and an annoying character for others.
Sakamichi no Apollon (also known as Kids on the Slope), is an anime known for it's jazz elements.  However, it is more about the life of a shy boy Kaoru, who learns what true friendship is through music.
The Good: The musical movements presented in this anime are so fluid and well animated, whether it be drumming or Kaoru playing on the piano.  Something I loved from the get-go was the friendship between Kaoru and Sentaro, and I still did by the end.
Sakamichi no Apollon is a drama with musical elements, andnot much more.  But, this anime seems to make me feel for the characters, and soothe me with inspirational jazz music.  The romantic elements seem realistic, although formulaic and very "Korean drama"\n\n
8.5/10

Let's face it... if you don't like music, you HATE this. If you do like music, you'll LOVE this. That is the presumption right? Right. 
But this anime turns out to be more than that. It's romance, music, action all intertwined together into a neat 13 episode paradise of an anime. There's something for everyone here. Those who could relate themselves through music. Those who could relate themselves though the misunderstanding of a loved one's action. Those who could relate themselves through the tragic that unfolds in ones family... 
For those who can't, and just watches this anime... you'll still find it blindingly brilliant. Okay...if you watch it all at once, you might find it slightly boring. But this anime, unlike so many others, are supposed to be watched with an week-in-between period/break. Therefore, if you take up my advice, and tempt your temptation to finish it all at once, you'll be captivated. 


What more is there to say? Umm.... oh yeah, if you find yourself starting to like Jazz because of this, then I applaud you. Thanks to this, I too started to appreciate the delicacy of Jazz, and the endless interpretation of this art form.


And so I conclude another short, but informative (?) and encouraging review. If you're still reading, allow me to display my humble appreciate in the form of a "thank you". Like I always say, all anime's welcome on my home road (hence AnimeRoad, see ;] , so I tend to stay neutral. 


Love you ALL

Sakamichi no Apollon is one of the animes where you want to ask the producer "Why? why did you have to destroy an almost perfect anime?". For the reason why...read the review :)
Sakamichi no Apollon centers about a group of high school students who love jazz music. And where is music there i also love. Plenty of love :).
The main character, Nishimi Kaoru, is bright student with good grades but not so good in makings any friends. He's changed many school so he's got used to be alone.
On the other hand Sentarou Kawabuchi is an energeting young men who prefers fighting and skipping school, atotal opposite of Nishimi.

Ritsuko Mukae is kind and gentle girl, probably the only friend of Sentaro, who will play a significant part in uniting them together.


It all starts when Nishima comes to a new school. Soon he hear rumors of a delinquent student who is in his class. Since he's the perfect target to be bulliied, he tries to stay away from him. (Un)forturnately he meets him on his very first day. In a little awkward situation Sentaro  helps him and soon they become friends. They learn that both of them play musical instruments and they start practising in a basement of Ritsuko's father music shop. Nishima soon meets two other band memebers Junichi Katsuragi and Ritsuko's father. From time to time they practice together and they made a small concert in a local bar. But... their problem comes, as usually, with love. It's not unusual to see love triangles in animes, but here we got a love pectagon, three boys (and to more dramatic all three of them are in the band) and two girls. If with a love triangle things can get complicated, imagine with a love pentagon. So from the midle of the anime there starts the frequents fights and reconcialitions between various main characters.After a while things get kind of sorted out and the anime begin to get concentrated on the music again. But almost at the end, when most are expecting a happy ending (with an 'epic' battle between jazz an rock bands in the school festival), the producer changes his mind and decides to make a dramatic event that will change everything. At the end we get a weird, neither happy nor sad ending.


The music is one of the strongest (if not the strongest points) of this anime. Although I'm  not a big fan of jazz music, thanks to this anime I started to get interested. There is a 'epic' moment in the anime, when Nishima and Sentaro performed at the school festival, which reminded me of a legendary scene from Beck (I've got a feeling performance at the festival).


Honestly, I  was hoping that the anime would be more concentrated on the music rather than the love events between the main characters. Unfortunately, it wasn't that way and the unnesecary dramatic event at the end ruined almost a masterpiece.


Don't get me wrong the anime is great, good characters and even greater music perfomances. But... But it could be even better. It started great but it ended bad :(.


The final score is 9 and only because I really loved the music. A deserved score would be 8.

This is true masterpiece!
Story revolves around a somewhat lost and depressed shoolkid who, thanks to meeting an amazing person, manages to overcome his own downsides and discover joy in life.
Story and characters.
There are many amazing characters and 2 main are shown in development. They both have very lovable personality and you just can't stop from falling in love.
Story is realistic and thought through. If you prefer stereotypical characters of shojo and action mangas this plot isn't for you. 
Art and sound.
Sound is perfect, both voice acting and music. There is a lot of really well done music pieces and no cheezy "disney-like" moments. Enjoy prettyawesoem jazz and a bit of rock'n'roll. \n
Art is done quite well. This anime is in semi-relaistic style, people aren't deformed and you can easily tell one character from another. I really loved design of characters and environment.\n\n
Enjoyment.\n
Though there are many very sad moments in "Kids on slope", overally this anime leaves you warm and fuzzy inside. I felt like crybaby in the end. \n\n
Despite main action happening in school, I'd suggest target audience for this story is older than 20, probably 25+. One needs to have a bit of life experience to fully enjoy the plot. This anime is a must watch for all who like realism and need a little boost to their souls.

I'll start by saying Sakamichi no Apollon wasn't perfect, but I enjoyed every episode to the extent that I couldn't stop - I had to watch the whole thing in one sitting. I feel nothing needs to be changed, and for that I give it a 10. 
* * * S T O R Y / C H A R A C T E R S* * *
Well, there isn't much of a plot, per se. They play jazz, but they don't try to form a successful band like in Beck. What you're left with is a story that revolves around the characters and theiremotions. In the end, the main point I got was that they consider friendship truer and more important than love. While I don't agree with that, I think it was fine in this anime. When it comes to love, the characters are confused, moody, and they have no idea what they want. Well, I suppose that's how most teenage love is. Indeed, having true friends is far more valuable than some temporary, whimsical relationship. 

They're pretty moody about their friendships, too, but only because they foolishly seek empty romance and act childish whenever something comes up. You might say it'd be better if they didn't act that way, but hey, they're still young and immature, and that stuff gave this series entertaining twists. As viewers, we tend to insist that "Boy" MUST be matched up with "Girl", but if the basis of their relationship is weak, should we really care about that? I was fine with how things turned out, though there was sorta one loose end. 

The characters changed throughout the series. I've seen quite a few series that didn't really have any character development; it's good that this series didn't forget about that aspect. Maybe some of their changes weren't for the best, but they were changes, nonetheless. Teens oughtta be going through changes, anyway! It was also good that they changed in that it progressed the story; we could've been sitting here for 24 episodes or more with no conclusion if it was your average indecisive love triangle.


* * * A R T * * *

The shading is a little blurred, giving it a more realistic look than the usual shading in anime. I thought it looked pretty nice, and it's also nice to see something different once in a while. The opening theme has beautiful artwork. The rest of the series might not be quite that nice, but it's still well done. Overall, the series gave me a different "feel" than your average anime. I mean, I'm used to seeing a hill to get to school, a city/town setting, a school setting, a random park that inevitably has some confession scene. Still, Sakamichi no Apollon somehow felt very different. I think it's probably because of how realistic they made everything look with the art, shading, and choice of colours. The characters also had normal looking faces, which is another plus. The animation was also rather smooth in many parts.


* * * S O U N D * * *

If you like jazz, you'll probably like the music in this. It has some nice pieces in it, some of which I recognized from hearing elsewhere. I think it made it much more enjoyable to see the characters happily jamming their worries away. The lively jazz gave those scenes the impact they aimed to have. 


This series manages to make rock music seem like a shallow and lifeless piece of shit. I'm not sure why they felt the need to take a stab at rock, but also not sure I really care. 


* * * E N J O Y M E N T * * *

You might think of it as yet another high school love triangle mess, but there are some key points that I think made Sakamichi no Apollon much better than the usual. This anime is set in a time before girls wore nothing but miniskirts, a time before girls had pink hair, a time before maid cafes were a necessity in a school festival, a time before 10 girls would be fawning over 1 guy, a time before high-pitched voices. Not only that, but this anime is safe from the greatest plague of all anime - "anime humour". You won't see "anime faces" like XD and ^o^. You won't see lame attempts at humour that fall flat. 

Honestly, I think all anime would be much better if they'd give up on that stuff. We don't need our entertainment watered down by fanservice and the same jokes we've already heard dozens of times. It's hard to find something like this. Even Hellsing, known for its intense violence and gore, is ruined by its occasional weak humour and typical anime content. The Berserk manga's value is also decreased by its "typical anime humour character", Puck - it's a miracle the Berserk anime took a serious route and excluded that character. I could go on forever listing anime that's been ruined by comedy/ecchi, such as Chobits. Humour doesn't belong in all anime. I'm glad Sakamichi no Apollon realized this.


* * * O V E R A L L * * *

Well, this is my idea of what anime should be like. Serious anime is more enjoyable than anime that inappropriately tries to inject comedy into the mix. If you're sick of moe, lolicons, harems, ecchi, large-breasted characters, filler arcs to defeat some no name enemy, overkilled jokes, common "anime faces" substituting emotions/real expressions... then I think you'll like this.

The thing that differentiates Kids on the Slope the most is the execution of the combination of sound and art.  It's the first time I've seen animation along with the music done correctly.
Aside from that, the story was well written.  I liked how everything was realistic, unlike most other anime.  The only thing that turned me off a little was the dramatic rampages from the piano guy.  The character interactions were really well done.  I felt like I could hang out with them.
The best part was the festival or anytime they were playing together.
So obviously, everyone see this anime.

I have nothing bad to say about this anime. I loved it from start to finish.
I loved the friendship between the two main characters, and the music was great. I'm not in jazz, but I really enjoyed the music. 
The anime left me feeling happy after watching every episode.. I still have a few episodes to go before I have completed this anime, and I am dreading it.. I don't want it to end.. but I know that if I have the time, I will be rewatching it. :)
The characters, the art, the music and everything else were great and to my tastes and liking.I would highly reccomend this anime to any anime fan. :)

I'm going to start by saying this, I love this anime. I do, this anime is great, it shows how people's lives were back in a golden age where there were a lot of troubles, be it political, emotional or even physical. The story for that matter is great, the way it follows there lives and how honest to truth it is is incredible. The art is amusing in a way that could draw you in, and the sound... well, it is an anime based around music so the sound is incredible. I thoroughly enjoyed this anime and highly suggest it!
Now, getting passed my positivethoughts, there are a number of things that really get on my nerves in this anime. *THIS SECTION WILL CONTAIN SPOILERS OF SOME SORT BUT I WILL KEEP IT TO A MINIMUM!* The women in this anime truly grind my gears, the way they are and the way they do things. I do not know if this was the way it was supposed to be because of the time period or whatever, but the two main female characters in which the two main male characters have a crush on really get on my nerves. Firstly, Ritsuko was nice at first, I thought this is a character i could really grow to enjoy, but then a few episodes in it hit me how much of a fragile pathetic character she really was! Misunderstandings, neglecting her own feelings, neglecting others for their feelings just because she can't handle her own. In short... A bitch! \n
Then there is Yurika, at first, once again, a nice character. A damsel in distress who is saved by the prince, first showing affection, that then moves on to using of sorts. Then, they destroyed her initial image and made her come across as a bitch of the highest magnitude. Understanding someone's feelings for her and yet going after someone else, all while stringing along the initial man. \n\n
That said, this anime is still very enjoyable and I advise it to anyone who is in the mood for a musical anime that will truly dig into your heart, especially if you lived through the time period it was set.

This is my very first review. Its only once in a while that you watch an anime that you just feel a natural urge to write about it and this is that such time 
There is nothing to say about this anime, but that its a masterpiece. The graceful story, the lovable and understanding characters, everything is so well done that the only problem with it is that it had to end. 
The music is fantastic, gracefully put together, with the art being a good representative of the 1960's era.
In summary, I loved this anime, and I would recommend it to anyone; especially -people whohate anime, to give it a try. If this doesn't change their mind, nothing ever will.

Watch this if you are lazy to read the manga. One who does not mind to miss a "few" chapters of it. Watch this if you are into BL stuff. One who completely drowns into fantasizing two men the moment they touch each other even if in reality they are just doing a high-five. Watch this if you are a jazz fan. One who has the skills to play such beautiful tunes or just like to listen to them or perhaps a critic who has too much information on every jazz song on the planet. Watch this if you are a fan of the shoujogenre of anime/manga. One who recognizes that this series is one of the best titles to date way before an anime adaptation is made or perhaps just like shoujo type art. Finally, watch this if you are one of those who likes music and anime in general. Combining two great interests leaves no one missing out on a great series and will never regret that they gave it a shot. P.S I wish i had Jun onii-san's sex appeal. Damn the guy just  gets her woman without doing any effort at all. All he needs to do is play the trumpet. I am jelly.

I love jazz, so it's no surprise that I loved Kids on the Slope. I loved it enough to marathon it in one night.
Playing music makes a fantastic coming of age metaphor. Jazz is particularly apt for this, it's a style that says "jump in, make something up, it's okay to make mistakes." The soundtrack and the fantastic characterization of the two leads (Kaoru and Sentaro) saved this show from being another nerd-meets-rebel cliche.
Yet, as much as I enjoyed the show, there are some problems. The first few episodes are difficult to get through because they throw us immediately into the characters' inner struggles beforewe even know or care about these people. This is solved around episode five when there are more external conflicts for them to deal with. To be fair, this is probably a symptom of condensing a longer manga into 12 episodes. The story doesn't have a lot of room to breathe.


The drama can get overwrought at times. This is particularly bad because in several cases, issues felt resolved to the viewer but never really were on screen.


The romances are convoluted and problematic (at least three scenes verge on sexual assault though, of course, this is never even recognized much less mentioned or addressed). Only one couple seems believable. To the shows credit, this is the only couple we see work out.


However, the biggest problem with the show is how it treats its girls. Only three girls have names--Sachiko, Sentaro's elementary aged sister; Ritsuko, Sentaro's childhood friend and Kaoru's love interest; and Yurika, Sentaro's (and another character who will not be named because spoilers) love interest.


Just by reading that, it becomes apparent that these girls are only defined by their relationships with the boys around them. While Kaoru and Sentaro and the supporting cast around them--hip jazz trumpeter Jun, the dorky Marou, superstar wanna be Seiji, hell, even "Pops", Ritsuko's father, is more interesting than she is--are all rich, human, amazing characters. Ritsuko and Yurika are supposed to become really close friends (and kudos to the show for that because it would have been easy to cast them as catty rivals) but they NEVER once discuss anything but their romantic entanglements. We see the male characters argue about mundane things, get into fights, discuss musicians and records and their love of making music. Ritsuko and Yurika are allowed no such life. They function as plot devices to add more angst, to swoon and to be swooned over, and change this from a "Beck" style battle of the bands seinen show to a josei one. Even little Sachiko gets plot deviced.


All that being said, let's get to the good stuff.


The character's expressions were so perfectly animated that they could have been on human actors. 


The voice acting in the sub was pitch perfect.


The setting and time period were interesting and beautiful. The story is set in a rural Kyushu, and the contrast between the people there and the new kid, city boy Koaru is perfect. I'm assuming (based on fashion, the fact that the Beatles were just getting popular and the Communist movement was taking off) that it was also set in the early 1960's, which really added a classic, nostalgic feel to the show. Perfect for casting it as memories of youth gone by.


One thing the show does really well is romanticize youth without calling it the best time of life. We see the characters grow up and they are happy and healthy in their adult lives.


And, of course, Yoko Kanno means the soundtrack is amazing. If you have any knowledge of jazz, get why the episode names are all so perfect (hint: it's not just because their all song names), know the lyrics to the melodies played in a few places, or understand why "Moanin'" is such a perfect song to be the true theme of the show, then you're in for a real treat.


I've seen criticism of Kids on the Slope for it's convoluted love...shapes. I think it's fair to say the show focuses too much on romance but in the end, the most important part of the show, the most endearing love, isn't a romance. It's the love between Kaoru and Sentaro expressed through music. As deftly expressed in the show, they have a special kind of "goofy" friendship that lasts longer than romantic love. It's the realization that the ending theme "Altair" is sung by Kaoru to Sentaro. It's what pulls our two boys and Ritsuko back together again at the very end after they've grown so much and so far apart.


Of course, while moving and heart warming, bromances have been the center of stories since ancient Greece. The boys' deep love isn't anything new or subversive.


Give Kids on the Slope a spin if you like things that are cool. Just beware that Ritsuko and Yuriko are unfairly more props than characters.

Do you like the 1960's? Do you like Jazz? Do you like shoujo? Do you like to ship couples? Well than Sakamichi no Apollon is the show for you! With many characters to love, and each having a different personality and relatable traits this anime will be sure to catch your attention. From episode one, I couldn't  stop watching. The music is done AMAZINGLY and so is the art!

I don't know why or how but music anime always catch's  me of guard. Such is Sakamichi no Apollon. I'll try to make this review as quick possible.
Story" 8/10 
The anime is about Kawabuchi, Sentarou and Nishimi, Kaoru and their devolopment threwout the episodes of building there friendship and love of jazz music. There is a romance between the two with Mukae, Ritsuko and it's well built mostly between them.
Characters" 10/10
I just loved all of them and could not get enough of them especially Kawabuchi, Sentarou. But, Nishimi, Kaoru, really was a true jerk threw out the anime. His character made me upset countlesstimes.



Art" 10/10

Beautifully animated with a unique style. I loved every episode and each episode was full of life.



Sound" 10/10

Not since Beck have a heard music done so well. 



Enjoyment" 10/10

I enjoyed the romance, Jazz and the cry's and fights between these characters. They made me believe life is not easy and there is always struggles throughout.




Overall score" 10/10

My review is short but I felt I needed to write a quickie for this anime. I once thought music anime was boring and dull. But not since Beck and now Sakamichi no Apollon have I said I will never underestimate the generation again. If you have a love for music in general you owe it to yourself to watch Sakamichi no Apollon.
